Reviews.Title: “OK - but too many minor failures”
Reviews.Author: sebastianflight
Reviews.Content: Nice enough place but we experienced a series of small disappointments which in total, left us less than thrilled. Hotel said we would be met at airport. We werenâ€™t. Said to have view of Hagia Sophia. Yes, but only dome and top of minarets, rest hidden by high wall. Said â€˜suiteâ€™ had private Turkish bath. No, it had a small wet room with a hot tap in it: that is NOT a â€˜Turkish bathâ€™. Breakfast adequate, except the coffee was watery and tasteless, suspicion of Nescafe, fine for Americans maybe.... No TV in room â€“ as it happens, I dont complain about that, but others might think that odd at this price. My wife wrote 3 letters over 3 days, left them with reception to post. On departure we found the letters still at reception â€˜as we only go to post twice a weekâ€™! Conclusion: cannot really recommend this place

Reviews.Title: “A quiet oasis in the midst of chaos”
Reviews.Author: DiniToronto
Reviews.Content: We were fortunate to have received a recommendation to stay at the Ayasofya Konaklari. The online pictures do not do it justice. It's a little piece of heaven located in the centre of a very busy and hectic city. Coming home to our room each day was something we looked forward to. Yes the rooms are a bit dated and could do with some refreshment but all that just adds to the charm. Rooms are very clean and the breakfast was lovely. The location is fantastic as it is in walking distance to most of the popular historical sites.

Reviews.Title: “low value; keep looking...”
Reviews.Author: tmbrod
Reviews.Content: Three nites here. First two were on a top floor in one of the street-fronting rooms. IT'S A LONG WAY UP THE NARROW STAIRS. Room was unbearably cramped (might have been bearable if we weren't paying about $275/nite!!!) and hot despite AC. Buffet breakfast was adequate but mediocre at best. Piles of dust balls under the bed! Third nite was in another building called the Garden rooms. I understand this room should have been much more expensive. It was small but fine. We spent 4 nites at the Amira Hotel (see my review among many other raves) for the same rate and it was heavenly.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, too much furniture in the rooms”
Reviews.Author: talktwojohn
Reviews.Content: The Ayasofya Konaklari mansions are conveniently located in the popular historic district of Sultanahmet, which is on the European side of Istanbul. The exterior offers a postcard perfect view, where a cobblestone street separates the Ayasofya mosque from the Ayasofya Konaklari. The mansions are a collection of century old timber-fronted mansions, once occupied by prominent Istanbul families but now run as tourist residences. Most of the properties have flowering climbers on the front elevations, and many people stop to take photos. Cost for a room on the streetside, with a double bed was 112 euro with breakfast. Staff greet you in a friendly fashion and show you where everything is in your room, and how they work. My room had a a view looking directly onto the Ayasofya mosque and cobbled street below, with safe, air conditioning and en-suite bathroom. When booking, it might be wise to ask for the second or top floor; I stayed on the first floor which was fine. My room was quiet and had no passing traffic as it is in a zone prohibited to vehicles. Air conditioning worked well, and helped keep the errant couple of mosquitoes at bay. The hotel staff booked taxis which arrived within minutes. Breakfast was buffet style with a good selection on offer. The rooms had nice varnished hardwood floors, but there is too much furniture in the room to appreciate this well. Rooms were clean but for two people, my double would have been a bit of a squeeze if you wanted to have a good sleep. I had my sleep of the just and was able to check out the night before, making time for an al-fresco breakfast fifteen minutes before the official breakfast time of 7am. My taxi for the ferry port of Yenikapi arrived on time. When I arrived at Istanbul airport, I was met by a driver pre-booked by arrangement by the Ayasofya Konaklari and whisked to the reception for 40 euro on a Sunday. I paid for what I got; a great location, a bit cramped, a filling breakfast and clean bed clothes. Perhaps I'd stay again, however I would probably experiment with a different residence for my next trip.

Reviews.Title: “Oasis in istanbul”
Reviews.Author: Aribaron
Reviews.Content: This was my 2nd stay here over 17 years and it lived up to my memory. Nestled against the walls of the topkapi palace across a quite street from the Haggia Sophia, the location is ideal. The hotel is in a row of wooden homes built at the turn of last century, so it feels like you are living in an old Victorian. The rooms are small, but adequate, the baths have been updated, the ac works well. The staff was lovely, and the garden where you take breakfast is beautiful.the street is blocked off to car traffic, so it offers a perfect home to return to after a busy day in istanbul..

Reviews.Title: “Old world charm & stunning location”
Reviews.Author: moroz
Reviews.Content: As other reviewers have said, the location is unbeatable, but this is not a plush hotel with all mod-cons. Rooms in the old traditional Ottoman houses are all upstairs (with no lifts), the bathrooms are small and fairly basic, the bedrooms are basic - no tea/coffee making facilities, no TV, no radio/alarm, no wifi (that is available in the coffee shop next to reception), and the selection of food at the breakfast buffet was disappointingly limited. We stayed just one night, for the experience, and it was a great experience, but we were pleased that we hadn't booked for a longer stay.

Reviews.Title: “A hidden gem - great value”
Reviews.Author: FrequentStayer0
Reviews.Content: We've visited Istanbul, as tourists, three times in the last few years. To get the best out of historic Istanbul, the only area to stay is Sultanahmet, the old city. Lots of options, ranging from the Four Seasons (which is terrific) to various guest houses and B&Bs. Ayasofya Konaklari is a fantastic choice, because of location, location, location. The location well and truly makes up for it not being a five star place, as does the lovely garden that's open on warm days and serves good value and qualify food at at a sensible price. It's also licensed and sells a reasonable selection of beers and spirits, along with local wines. Oh, and free WiFi too. And it's the only place I've ever stayed where other tourists were often taking photos of the place - this hotel is a series of separate, free-standing houses, not the usual kind of hotel building.

Reviews.Title: “You can't beat the location”
Reviews.Author: ocnana
Reviews.Content: This hotel has the most wonderful location. It backs up to the walls of the Topkapi Palace on a very quiet street in the old part of Istanbul. It is made up of a group of delightful homes with a beautiful terrace restaurant. The dinner we had was delicious and the buffet breakfast has everything you could possibly want. It was wonderful in the evening to be able to just walk up the road to the most famous sites in Istanbul and see everything lit up. It is also just up the street from the main square and just a few blocks from an area that has several blocks of restaurants on both sides of the street. If we are lucky enough to visit Istanbul again we would definitely stay in this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic Location, OK Hotel”
Reviews.Author: WorldTraveller1983
Reviews.Content: The location of this hotel is absolutely fantastic, with views onto the Aya Sofya and a few minutes walk to the Topkapi Palace, meaning you can get their first thing in the morning to avoid the crowds (a must because it gets very busy!). Although the hotel is in the centre of the city it is in a lovely peaceful area. The rooms however are very basic in terms of facilities - our bathroom was tiny and the beds were not that comfortable. The decoration is outdated, or 'charming' depending on your taste. Breakfast was served in the garden cafe and provided the usual turkish breakfast.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, quiet, charm... with some drawbacks”
Reviews.Author: flyingFrenchman29
Reviews.Content: Unbeatable location, just between Ayasofya and Topkapi, on a quiet pedestrian street. The hotel is split in 9 small traditional ottoman 3-storey houses with lots of charm. Rooms and bathrooms are small but clean, their decoration is somewhat outdated; bathrooms are rather basic ; beds are not big but comfortable. Service is adequate although reception staff may be a bit cold. No room service. Breakfast takes place in a nice garden house - a bit far if you are in house 9 as we were. Breakfast food is quite disappointing, not to the standard expected : juices are not fresh, honey and jam is from small plastic boxes, tea is Lipton tea, etc... There is wifi, but it did not work equally well throughout the hotel and our house had no connection. No TV, but we did not miss it. Overall we found that it is an expensive but still charming hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Right in the target ( but why without a TV? )”
Reviews.Author: vasilevn
Reviews.Content: This is my second choice for hotel in Istanbul and regardless the lack of TV in our rooms (which happens to me for the first time ever in a hotel), I can recommend Ayasofya Konaklari mainly because of the good service and his location. Our rooms were in the main building, but the hotel has some more luxurious houses along the back wall of the Hagia Sophia. Overall the place is an excellent starting point for excursions and sightseeing tours and walks. Breakfast is more than good (for a hotel in Istanbul), there's even an omelet. Internet access is not available, but also as the TV is quite possible to not notice its absence. If you come with a car, the hotel offers a small parking lot, but ask in advance for an assistance from how to come - since a few months the whole central part of Istanbul is closed to cars and getting to the hotel is almost impossible ( only my experience save me this time )

Reviews.Title: “My favourite place to stay in Istanbul - one of my favourite cities!”
Reviews.Author: BunclodySenator
Reviews.Content: I have stayed over 50 times at this wonderful boutique hotel, and look forward to visiting many more times, G-D Willing. Murat Ozturk, the manager, and Mrs. Fulya, are by now very dear friends, and, while I can be demanding sometimes, have never been anything but the most courteous, helpful, supportive and wonderful of hosts. And, while I have found this more the norm than the exception in my almost 80 visits (so far!) to Turkey, they still seem to go that extra bit further. I must say that tourists need to be careful of the name, because, though I warned them, some friends from Jerusalem, who had been told to book the Ayasofya Konaklari or Atasofya Pansiyonlari ONLY, instead booked the Ayasofya Hotel, a dreadful fleabag of a place, and not at all the same thing. On one detail, I must correct my dear friend Murat - from the top floor of the White House (Konuk Evi), the free-standing house in the same courtyard where one eats the delicious buffet breakfast (and don't forget to ask for a fresh omelet - they are wonderful, even if the waiters laugh when I slather it with ketchup!), one can see the waters of the Halic or Golden Horn. However, from there, one can't see any garbage-laden areas. The person who complained, must have stayed at the Ayasofya hotel, or another place with a similar name. The tramway, which is very convenient from the hotel, is a great way to get around. I go down the hill to the stop just below the exit from the Yerebetan Sarnic (Cistern), and when I return, I go to the next stop, Sultanahmet, so I don't have to walk back up the steep hill (or if I'm coming from the other direction, I simply get off at Sultanahmet stop, which is near the famous (or infamous) Puddingshop.). Incidentally, while not a five star hotel (and the prices definitely reflect that!), there is room service, and, in the cafe/library next to and up a few steps from the hotel office, there is a computer with internet, which guests may use. I check email there (just remember - in Turkish there are two "i"s, one with a dot on top (like in English, etc), one without. The regular one is to the right on the keyboard, while the one without, is located where the "i" is usually found. It is a bit confusing). They don't have TVs, but if you ask, they will put one in your room. I usually prefer without. Next door to Konuk Evi (sort of), is a wonderful handicraft centre in a genuine Madresse (school) by Mimar Sinan Pasha, called the Ceferiye Medrese (pronounced 'Jafari-yeh) with classes in Turkish arts (like Ebru, Marbling paper - I studied for a week with Ayla Makas - a brilliant lady , an amazing artist, and very patient (I'm ADHD and mild Asperger's, so she is REALLY patient!)), and it has a great little restaurant. There is another beautiful handicraft centre with superb things, next to Yesil Ev (Green House) hotel, another 'Turing' establishment, 5-10 min. walk away. Beautiful embroideries, calligraphy, miniatures, etc., at very reasonable prices, considering the objects are not churned out by the million. Both places, and also the gallery run by Coskun (pron. Joshkoon), have beautiful objects shown and sold by wonderful, friendly, truly hospitable people. Finally, a last word about the Sarnic (Cistern ) Restaurant in the hotel - it is amazing! the food is great but the atmosphere is even better - a Byzantine cistern with huge pillars and a fire place, with 30 or more foot ceiling. In summer, however, I prefer the courtyard near the fountain. By the way, either place will supply you with food from both menus - the cafe one from the courtyard, and the fancier one from the Cistern. They are always willing to accommodate.

Reviews.Title: “Unbeatable Location on Pedestrian Only Lane”
Reviews.Author: Sacromonte
Reviews.Content: This beautifully located hotel consists of several 19th century Ottoman row houses between the Hagia Sophia and the Topkapi Palace wall. The fact that there is no traffic can only be appreciated once you have braved the hordes of tourists and tour buses of Sultanahmet. I stayed here three nights as part of a small group tour. The staff is extremely gracious and accommodating. There is a lovely courtyard restaurant.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent service in the historic heart of Istanbul in a calm, pedestrian, picturesque street”
Reviews.Author: Blahernai
Reviews.Content: The room and the bathroom needs a bit refurbishment. However, we were more than pleased from our stay and would go back. The breakfast buffet should be richer.

Reviews.Title: “Scandalous!”
Reviews.Author: Rommersomconnection
Reviews.Content: The room that we got was so small that you had to choose: or to open the suitcases, or to try to sleep in bed. The room was basically a bed surrounded by four walls. The bed was too small for two persons (and we are both rather short). ... and this for 170 euro/night?! Scandalous! We planned to stay 5 nights. First thing what we did in the morning ... after a very disappointing breakfast ... was looking for a new hotel. We have visited many places, but this beats everything. Just scandalous!

Reviews.Title: “Lovely - but no internet unfortunately....”
Reviews.Author: KMCanberra
Reviews.Content: Konaklari is known by a number of names including Pension Konaklari and Turing Hotel Konaklari, but in any case almost certainly wonâ€™t be recognised by any taxi driver you encounter â€“ so have a high quality map handy, or get out at Meydan Ayasofya (the square outside Ayasofya) and walk from there â€“ itâ€™s only a couple of minutes around the corner. The hotel consists of a number of three-storey wooden houses in an intriguing street all of its own, sandwiched between the rampart wall of Topkapi Palace and the back of Ayasofya. Most of the houses seems to be newly built but modelled on old Istanbul ones, and are really gorgeous both inside and out. Views from the â€˜streetside roomsâ€™ which are the best ones arenâ€™t all that memorable because Ayasofya is really too close! â€“ but itâ€™s an excellent location and very, very quiet â€“ in fact the street outside is private, and completely closed to traffic at night. Breakfast is OK but the coffee is terrible; we asked for Turkish instead and maybe if more people do the same theyâ€™ll do something about the quality of the stuff in the jug. Staff were very helpful. It's such a high quality place that I was completely amazed there is no internet in the room; they did tell me a computer is available in the coffee shop up the steps next to reception, though I didn't try it in the end - weaned myself off the internet for a few days instead! The fact there is no TV is simply wonderful - it makes the room so homely.

Reviews.Title: “GREAT LOCATION - AVERAGE QUALITY”
Reviews.Author: CultureTravellerOslo
Reviews.Content: My partner and I just spent eight nights at Ayasofya Konaklari. The location is perfect, the pension and its rooms have an attractive Ottoman atmosphere, and the surroundings are surprisingly quiet considering this is the heart of Istanbul. People considering staying at Ayasofya should be aware that this is indeed a pension. It is not a five star hotel. The room we stayed in was decoratively furnished and clean, but the beds were rock hard, and there was no TV or radio. The breakfast is decent, but almost every day we noticed that the omlet or the boiled eggs would run out without the waiters filling up with new reserves. The waiters in the breakfast room were not particularly friendly or welcoming, nor was the staff at the reception. They seemed quite indifferent to the fact that we spent a long time - eight nights - in their establishment. All in all - we were not dissatisfied with our experience, but we are certain you can get better value for money elsewhere in istanbul.

Reviews.Title: “Best location, great service, simply loved it.”
Reviews.Author: minosa00
Reviews.Content: We travel all over the world. This hotel is in our top 10. The hotel is in a unique location. Right in the heart of the old city but you do not feel that you are in the middle of the city because it is very peacefull and quiet, between the Saint Sophia and the Topkapi Palace. The hotel is in a pedestrian street with walking distance from the major sight seeing places. We stayed 5 days. It was a wonderfull stay and we strongly recommend the place. If you want to stay in Istanbul for sight seeing this is one of the places you shoud stay.

Reviews.Title: “good location, bad 50's furniture & fixtures...............”
Reviews.Author: traveltime051
Reviews.Content: We recently stayed for 5 nights. We booked one of the apartments and were told on arrival "I've chosen a wonderful room with a beautiful water view for you"......well.... the view was a tree until a little old man cut it down (as I was packing to leave) so that we could see the rubbish in the vacant block in front of us. We waited 2 days for the TV to be fixed & that was after convincing the front desk that we were not complete morons & knew how to use a TV. We really didn't need the TV but the attitude left a lot to be desired. We asked every day for 5 days that someone look at our water heater which oscillated between cold & hot without notice, that was a worry when trying to wash my 10 year olds hair but that was never attended to & our beds were not attended to in the 5 days we stayed. Also before I left I finally removed the spider webs from the old creaky chairs myself. Staff in the breakfast room were very welcoming.

Reviews.Title: “Good location, quitet side street and impeccable service”
Reviews.Author: KariOslo
Reviews.Content: Stayed here with my 7 colleagues for a short weekend (fri-sun) and we very satisfied with the hotel. Prior to our visit, the hotel offered to organise different activities for us if needed. So, airport transit, tour guide (a very good one, for the price of 120 euros for one day), visits to hammam and restaurant bookings were all taken care of when we arrived. This made our entire stay run very smoothly. In general, the service was impeccable - very friendly staff all around, from front desk to breakfast attendants. The breakfast could be enjoyed in the quiet backyard, which was also a nice experience. Yes, the rooms are a bit old, but we found this charming. Above all, it was clean and nice - and that is really what you need. Locationwise, it was perfect for strolling around seeing all the main sights in Sultanehmet.

Reviews.Title: “Location isn't everything with this hotel!”
Reviews.Author: NYCtravelagent
Reviews.Content: On the recommendation of a friend we booked this hotel. It is a good location to visiting the major sites in Sultanhamet. BUT - if you want to pay 5 star prices but receive 2 star service , then keep reading. The rooms are old and musty. The showers leak and are in a standing enclosure fit for only someone who is a size 2. My husband found it impossible to move around . We had booked a suite and the difference in price is certainly not worth it. For the price paid for a suite, it's a far better value to go to the Four Seasons or any other luxury hotel in Istanbul. The only advantage was free Wifi offered.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent location but poor value”
Reviews.Author: DavidHManchester
Reviews.Content: Certainly the best location and atmosphere in old Istanbul, but the small size of the rooms (especially bathrooms) and basic services make the price hard to justify. Breakfasts OK and in delightful garden location but the charm of the conservatory spoiled by its filthy roof. The calls to prayer are VERY loud and intrusive. Having said all this, very glad we stayed there and didn't see anywhere else we'd rather be.

Reviews.Title: “The Sultan's-Eye View Alone Is Worth It”
Reviews.Author: EvilTwin2000
Reviews.Content: Frankly, this hotel is a bit out of my price range. But I had to splurge for a couple of nights if only for the incredible close-up views of Aya Sofya. I wasn't disappointed. The staff were friendly and attentive at check-in and throughout my visit. These folks seemed to be looking for ways to enhance their guests' experience--it's nothing I can put my finger on, and I'm not very demanding anyway. But even I could tell that service standards were high. I never had a problem communicating in English. The breakfast is pleasant if typical, but the greenhouse where it's served is lovely and maybe even elegant. As mentioned in other reviews, the location is absolutely unbeatable, smack dab between Aya Sofya and the grounds of Topkapi Palace on a street that is closed to thru traffic at night. The recent refurbishment must have been a success because I saw no signs of shabiness. As a frequent solo traveller, I'm used to getting the smallest room in the hotel. And the room here was small too, but interestingly appointed with some Ottoman style furnishings. It didn't matter. The selling point here is the view, and it's a doozy: my grandmother could have hit Aya Sofya with a rock from my window. It's as close as you can get to sleeping *in* Aya Sofya. I can't tell you how many times I was drawn to that window, if only to look out and say to myself, "I am the sultan," and very nearly believing it. So people who are prone to power trips probably shouldn't stay here. But everybody else should. Istanbul is one of my very favorite cities, and though there's a less expensive hotel I frequent, I will find a way to juggle the budget on future visits so I can stay here at least a night or two. It's that striking. By the way, complaining about the call to prayer in Istanbul is like complaining about how anoying all those church bells are in Rome.

Reviews.Title: “perfect setting for first istanbul sightseeing trip”
Reviews.Author: evanston_doc
Reviews.Content: We spent 4 nts here where the apartments are attached to the Topkapi Palace. Despite adjacency to the Blue Mosque, the 5 am call to prayer is not at all unpleasant contrary to other posts. The tramline which hits all the major tourist sites is within a few hundred yards downhill - making the new district also quite reachable. They have wifi in the cafe, not sure if in the rooms, and have a single computer for public use. Staff are pleasant and polite, although beyond basic tourist english, can be more of a challenge for communication. The attached restaurants including the included breakfast (which does not change, but they will make you an omelet and espresso if you inquire) are in nice settings with the ayasofya and blue mosques looming in the backdrop. However, for price, the adjacent Hotel Ottoman Palace appears to have all the same advantages just no historical charm, and I suspect is better equipped inside. Check out the calligraphy madrassa in the alley adjacent for a delightful, simple place to catch lunch.

HotelInfo.Name: Ayasofya Konaklari
HotelInfo.Address: Sogukcesme Street, Sultanahmet, Istanbul 34122, Turkey (Formerly Ayasofya Pension)
